A few patches after that disastrous 4.5.0 patch, the game is in a considerably better state. I got used to the new UI (at smallest scale possible) and the hitboxes/desync are mostly gone (for now), as are the other issues mentioned in my old review.

The game is fun under certain circumstances. If you have at least one friend to play with as survivor, it is a much more entertaining experience. As a solo Q player, you will have days where you get straight up awful matches (camping/tunelling killers and/or bad teammates) and days when your games will be satisfying and fun. You must have the nerve for it.

As far as killer is concerned, it is also a mental excerise. If you want chill games, you can dodge SWF groups and keys in lobbies, since the killer queues are extremely short. If you can't be bothered with that, try to distance yourself from any toxicity that you may come across. Avoid the flashlight clickers because this annoys the hell out of them. Break chases if they take too long. When it comes to camping or tunneling, think about how you feel when another killer does it to you. Seriously unfun and boring. But hey, if you want to do it, knock yourself out, it's your game.

All in all, if you want to be good at this game, you need to give it a lot of time. Probably a lot more that most games out there. Make no mistake, this is no casual game, no matter how they try to promote it that way. You need time to learn the mechanics of killer and survivor and you need experience in order to be able to work well with your teammates and predict your opponents' moves. If you plan to play this for a couple of hours every weekend, save you money and your time and look for something else. 


REVIEW FROM THE 4.5.0 PATCH (in order to remember what BHVR can do to this game)
I cannot recommend the game in its current state. The latest "patch" has brought some awful changes, that make DBD almost unplayable. First of all, the absolutely horrendous new UI. Before the patch, all the info that a player should be aware of while playing were neatly placed in the bottom left and right of the screen, in a perfectly working hud that did not need any change whatosever. After the patch, all that info is spread all around the screen, which makes it very hard to keep track of everything, while also limiting your field of view. This new setup is that of a mobile game, but if you play on pc or, even worse, on your console with a big TV, you will struggle. Additionally, the life meters of the survivors are so minuscule that you can barely see the progress bar. All in all, there is nothing that I like about the new UI - even the character portraits look out of place, the 'adept' portraits would have been a much better fit.

The new animations of the survivors feel extremely stiff and robotic. Plus they come with the bonus (a bug?) of way bigger hitboxes that let killer hits connect from ridiculous distances, thus making it extremely hard and frustrating to play as a survivor. Also, the "Unbroken" emblem is, well, broken and it will not reward any points if you don't actually survive the match, which means: a) less bloodpoints awarded, and b) unfair de-ranking. There are also lots of bugs that have appeared on new (walk-though walls in Asylum) and old maps (funbus) after this patch.

So until all these have been dealt with properly, no don't buy this game.

So, I know what you're thinking. Why is somebody with over 1,000 hours in this game writing a negative review? Well, the answer is simple. This game has it's moments. I've played it a lot, and have had fun with it for the most part. However, there is a glaring problem with the game, that is destroying everything I love about it, and upsetting the community more and more every day.

Pros

So, as you've probably seen, DBD is an asymmetrical horror game. Although I wouldn't really call it a horror game anymore, it's more of just a competitive game now. But the first few times you play, the game is terrifying. It's good fun to play survive with friends and get your socks scared off, or just to have a casual horror experience. But, as I said, the more you play, the game gets less and less scary, and more competitive. Don't take this as a bad thing, because the competitive part of the game is what keeps me and everyone else playing it. It has very addicting and fun gameplay. The game gives you your money's worth, and DLCs are not necessary to have fun in the game. Overall, this game is very fun if you're interested in the horror genre, or if you're looking for a rather simple competitive game to play, especially with friends.

Mine (and everyone else's) problem with the game

Now that I've covered why I've played the game so much and keep coming back to it, let's get into the reason why this game is so very controversial. The one and only thing that has been destroying this game and ruining everybody's experience with it, are the developers. Time and time again, the developers proceed to show just how out of touch they are with their own game.

Balance

There have been many many perks, addons, and killers that the community has been asking for changes for for actual YEARS. Either because it is too strong, or just because it's too unbalanced for the other side. The meta for the game is usually just the same perks every single match, because they rarely ever release newer strong perks, substantially buff other worse perks, or nerf the perks in the meta. And don't get me wrong, there are a LOT of perks in the game to choose from, it's just that there are very few perks that are actually decent in helping you survive/kill. After a while, the game becomes extremely stale because of these reasons.

Unwanted/questionable changes

Despite the meta in the game never changing, the developers of the game are constantly releasing new content. They release new killers and survivors very frequently, and with those updates come balance changes and "quality of life" changes. However, if I'm being completely honest, these changes are rarely ever good. Whenever they buff a perk, it's still not very good. Whenever they release a killer, it's usually not a viable killer. And the "quality of life" changes for the game that the developers think are good, are almost never good. All of these things make you wonder... do they developers even understand their own game, after all of this time working on it? A recent example of changes that nobody wanted is the recent "new and improved" UI. Don't get me wrong, the old UI was perfectly fine. All of the information you needed to know was neatly packed in the bottom left/bottom right side of the screen. However, when the developers came out with a PTB (player test build) showing the new UI, everything is now scattered all over the screen, and harder to see by people with vision disabilities. So, as expected, the community told the developers that this new UI wasn't good, and that it shouldn't be added to the live game. A month passes, and the mid-chapter update is finally released. And, to the shock of the whole community, hardly ANYTHING was changed from the UI on the PTB. It's still the scattered mess that it was a month before. This begs the question: what was the point of the PTB if the developers didn't listen to the community census?

Bugs

If you start playing this game, I'm sure you will immediately start running into bugs. With every update to the game, there is some weird new bug. Some of the bugs are just funny visual bugs that don't affect gameplay, but some bugs completely lose the game for you if you play killer, and some bugs can get you killed if you play survivor. And occasionally, there will be a bug that survivors find that can be extremely abusable, but instead of fixing it, the developers just ban people that they find doing it. This can lead to people unknowingly finding a bug and getting banned for no reason. Also, the game's servers can be extremely janky and laggy at times, which make some of the hits the killer gets on you look like they hit you from very far away. This sometimes makes the game unplayable.

Greed

As previously mentioned, the developers have a new killer released every 3 months, and they have shown to stick to this schedule very tightly, an example being the most recent chapter: A Binding of Kin. On paper, the new killer, The Twins, was a pretty unique idea for the game. You were able to control two characters at once throughout the map. However, as usual, this killer wasn't very strong. And, for this update, there was an UNGODLY amount of bugs with the new killer/reworked maps. And, as everyone pointed out in the PTB, the devs made a massive oversight on a very simple way to counter the new killer, which was just to go into a locker whenever the killer was using their power. Despite all of the bugs still unfixed and all of the counters to the new killer still standing, the time was coming where they were supposed to be releasing the new killer on schedule. Did they delay the chapter to fix the amount of bugs, or tweak the killer's power? You guessed it: no. They stuck to their schedule and released the update in a complete buggy mess. This just shows that the developers only care about the income for new chapters rather than the community.

Conclusion

After all I have to say about DBD, I still encourage you to buy it if you are interested in the genre. This is the only somewhat decent asymmetrical horror game on the market, and like I said, it has its moments of good fun. However, if you're willing to stick around, be prepared for godawful updates to the game that completely ruin it for you, and be prepared to be angry at the developers for their bad decisions.

TL;DR: The game is fun at times, but the developers make terrible updates and changes for the game that make them seem extremely out of touch and ruin the game for the community.
